I don't know enough type theory to properly formulate this question, but I noticed the following curiosity and wonder if there is something more to say about it that "it's just how it is".

For basic values the type heirarchy is - 3: Nat, Nat: Type, Type : Type 1 and so on.
but for proofs it is rlf: 3 = 3, 3 = 3: Prop and Prop: Type

It is somewhat surprising for me that the proof side has "extra depth". I got a good answer from claude about why Props have to diverge from the rest of the types (impredicability, proof invariance), but not why can't I expect that if we start with 3 and rfl as basic building blocks the same number of questions "what is this type of" don't end up in the same object, i.e. why isn't Prop: Type 1?

It has to do with how "big" the types can get.

rfl : 3 = 3 and 3 = 3 : Prop. 3 = 3 lives in Prop, so it can only every be a docs#Subsingleton.
3 : Nat and Nat : Type. Nat lives in Type, so can be bigger than 3 = 3. Nat has many different elements.
Cardinal.aleph0.{0} : Cardinal.{0} and Cardinal.{0} : Type 1. Cardinal.{0} is too big to fit in Type, so it has to be promoted to a Type 1. This reflects the fact that in ZFC, Cardinal numbers are a proper class.

As for why we don't have Prop : Type 1, this is so that the universes can be nicely ordered. Remember that Prop is an abbreviation for Sort 0, and Type u is an abbreviation for Sort (u + 1). Having Sort 0 : Sort 2 would just be weird.

I think that Prop : Type is just a weird coincidence of Lean's type theory. I don't teach it in my course. I tell students that there are universes (two of them, Prop and Type), types (e.g. statement of FLT, the real numbers) and terms (e.g. proof of FLT, 37).

There was a version of Automath that considered proofs to be at "degree 4", and they had a rule that terms of degree 4 were definitionally equal, tidily giving proof irrelevance. #new members > question about bool vs Prop @ ðŸ’¬
You might like this picture @Rado Kirov : #new members > question about bool vs Prop @ ðŸ’¬

This was all very helpful, thanks for link to the past discussion and indeed the diagram was exactly what I was looking for @Kyle Miller . Adding n => Fin n to the picture helps a lot.

Also that thread lead me to read @Kevin Buzzard https://xenaproject.wordpress.com/2020/06/20/mathematics-in-type-theory/ post and indeed Prop : Type feels like more of a design choice (since everything needs a type) than the obvious thing. Thinking about three layered hierarchy - terms, types, universes (with some type of relations between universes), seems to be the right way to do it, and not something I expected when I asked the question.

Funny enough, I used to teach TypeScript courses to software engineers, and they will often get throw off by the value (term in FP and Lean) vs type difference, especially with TS's fancier type system that has singleton types like let x: 3 = 3. But when your types don't have types, things are simpler :) We will tell people just to look syntactically are you in a type-position, i.e. after the : or not.
Rado Kirov has marked this topic as resolved.
